column8: 1) The Mid Columbia bus consists of switchyards

busses, you must schedule  with a 'BPA recognized control area'
interconnected with BPA at Mid C.

column8:
(1) As the point where the +/- 1000-kV Pacific Northwest DC Line crosses the Nevada-Oregon border, NOB is the control area tiepoint between BPA and LDWP, so there is no "host control area" per se. 
(2) NOB is not a trading hub in the formal sense;  energy may not be dropped off or "picked up" there without associated transmission to Celilo (the northern terminal) or to Sylmar (the southern terminal).  To schedule on SCE's, SDGE's or PG&E's rights (among others), one should contact a CaISO Scheduling Coordinator.
column9: From NOB to Sylmar, the CA is actually LDWP.  We sometimes encounter checkout problems when people incorrectly put "CISO" as the control area on the tag.  I believe the confusion may be caused by:   the fact that CISO Participating Transmission Owners currently own a  majority of the transmission capacity there, and  the fact that CISO is the CA in charge of the COB to Sylmar path (on which, incidentally, LDWP has rights).  The strange result of this is that LDWP must contact CISO to schedule from COB to Sylmar, and CISO must contact LDWP to schedule from NOB to Sylmar.

column2: Tie Point Participants = Control areas that physically interconnect to tie point.  May have rights on one or more lines or equipment which is tied to the point.
Line/Equipment Participants = Companies who have rights on this line or piece of equipment.  May or may not be a control area.
